Award.AwardTitle: Combinatorics, algebra, and geometry of face numbers
Award.AbstractNarration:
Geometric combinatorics is a rapidly developing field that has close connections to optimization, computer science, engineering, statistics, and even mathematical biology. A typical problem in optimization involves optimizing a function over the set of all solutions of a given linear system --- a system that usually contains hundreds or thousands of equations in many variables. Geometrically, the corresponding set of points is a high-dimensional object, called a polytope. Moreover, in recent years the study of polytopes with certain symmetry has led to surprising implications in statistics, probability, information theory, and signal processing, and is also expected to have impacts in such subjects as medical imaging and digital communications. In engineering and computer science, e.g., robotics, one often needs to describe a space of "allowed motions": this space can usually be approximated by a collection of points, segments, triangles, pyramids, and higher dimensional analogs of pyramids nicely glued together --- an object known as a simplicial complex. The problems aimed at deepening our understanding of polytopes and simplicial complexes are at the heart of this proposal.

The primary aim of this proposal is to attack several long-standing problems and conjectures in the theory of face numbers of various classes of simplicial and, more generally, CW complexes. Specifically, research on this project will involve the use of algebraic, geometric, topological, and combinatorial methods to attack fundamental enumerative questions related to (1) simplicial spheres and, more generally, complexes embeddable in a sphere of a given dimension, (2) balanced triangulations of spheres and manifolds, (3) flag and banner complexes, and (4) centrally symmetric polytopes. The main flavor of questions we are interested in is how the topology of the underlying space (e.g., being a triangulation of a certain manifold) or a certain combinatorial restriction, such as symmetry or balancedness, affects the possible face numbers of complexes in question. Although most of the problems proposed here are combinatorial in nature, recent advances are carried out by a subtle combination of algebraic and geometric arguments (among them Lefschetz algebras, generic and not-so-generic initial ideals, local cohomology, rigidity, etc.). Thus solutions to the proposed problems may impact not only combinatorics and discrete geometry but also such fields as combinatorial algebra, algebraic topology, and Riemannian geometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal was aimed at attacking several long-standing problems and conjectures in the theory of face numbers of various classes of simplicial complexes. A simplicial complex is constructed from points, line segments, triangles, pyramids, and higher-dimensional analogs of pyramids (called simplices) by gluing these objects so that every two of them are either disjoint or intersect along their common face.  Examples of simplicial complexes include polygons, pyramids, triangulations of polygons, and their higher-dimensional generalizations. For instance, a graph is a one-dimensional simplicial complex. Simplicial complexes are among the central objects in the field of geometric combinatorics --- a rapidly developing field that has close connections to optimization, computer science, engineering, statistics, and even mathematical biology. Below we outline several main outcomes of the proposal.

 One of the central questions in the field is how the topology of a simplicial complex (e.g., being a triangulation of a sphere or of a more complicated space) impacts its possible face numbers. Intuitively, the more complicated the topology of the space is the more simplices are needed to triangulate such a space. Several precise results as well as long-standing conjectures supporting this intuition exist in the literature, among them a conjecture by Gil Kalai positing  a low bound on the number of edges of a triangulated manifold in terms of the minimum number of generators of the fundamental group along with dimension and the number of vertices. (A manifold is a space that near each point looks like a disc; manifolds provide vast generalization of spheres.)  In a joint work with Satoshi Murai, the PI proved this conjecture.

 In the last decade, tremendous amount of research went into understanding the face numbers of triangulations of manifolds without boundary. However, the face numbers of manifolds with boundary remained a big mystery. (A manifold with boundary is a space that near each point looks like a disc or like half a disc.)  In another project with Satoshi Murai, the PI transferred and generalized a large portion of what was known about face numbers of triangulations of manifolds to manifolds with boundary, thus, at least partially, remedying the situation.

 A d-dimensional simplicial complex is called balanced if its vertices can be colored in d+1 colors, so that no two adjacent vertices receive the same color. (One example is the octahedron with a coloring that assigns a separate color to each pair of antipodal vertices.) In joint projects with Ivan Izmestiev, Steven Klee, Martina Juhnke-Kubitzke, Satoshi Murai, and Connor Sawaske, the PI developed tools for studying such complexes as well as established balanced analogs of several celebrated classic results.

 Broader impacts:  the PI is supervising graduate students, serves on the editorial boards of the Journal of Algebraic Combinatorics and SIAM Journal on Discrete Mathematics, and co-organizes various international conferences and workshops. She also co-organizers the Combinatorics seminar at the University of Washington.

 This grant supported the PI’s and her graduate students’ talks at conferences and workshops as well as several research stays. It provided Research Assistantships for the PI's graduate students allowing them to focus on research. It also allowed her to bring visitors to the University of Washington, which in turn allowed the PI and her graduate students to start new international collaborations.
